PHASE III 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
December 2002

NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by Jayant Menon, Economist, Regional Economic Monitoring Unit

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At  a  meeting  in  Jakarta  in  February  1998,  finance  ministers  of  the  Association  of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) broached the concept of an ASEAN economic surveillance 
process. The concept was predicated on assistance from the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
Extensive consultations on the objectives and scope of this assistance subsequently took place 
between ADB and officials of ASEAN member governments. ADB also consulted with the 
International Monetary Fund (IMF) on its support for the ASEAN economic surveillance process. 
 
2.  In October 1998, the ASEAN finance ministers assented to a "Terms of Understanding 
for the Implementation of an ASEAN Surveillance Process" (TOU). The process as outlined in 
the TOU anticipates close collaboration between ASEAN, ADB, and IMF. The TOU also directs 
that the ASEAN surveillance process (ASP) be supported by the establishment of an ASEAN 
Surveillance Coordination Unit (ASCU) within the ASEAN secretariat in Jakarta. ASCU will be 
responsible for coordinating, reviewing, consolidating, and preparing all surveillance materials 
for consideration by the ASEAN Select Committee (comprising deputies of finance ministries 
and central banks) and by the ASEAN finance ministers' meetings. ASCU will also coordinate 
surveillance  matters  between  individual  ministries,  central  banks,  and  other  institutional 
structures within ASEAN. 
 
3.  The ASEAN finance ministers' meeting formally requested ADB on 10 November 1998 
to  provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  training  and  capacity  building  in  support  of  ASP. 
Following a Fact-Finding Mission to ASCU in December 1998, ADB approved a regional TA1 in 
the same month. In this program, 3-5 ASEAN officials were seconded to ADB for approximately 
3 months to undergo training in surveillance-related issues. The TA ended in May 2002 after 
training 27 officials from the ASEAN countries. To complement the training program, TA 60192 
was processed in 2002. This TA provides shorter (3 weeks) but more intensive and structured 
training for busy mid-level ASEAN officials from the ministries of finance and central banks.  As 
of October 2002, 32 officials (in two cohorts) have been trained under this TA.   
 
4.  The deputy finance ministers of ASEAN have requested the continuation of ADB support 
for  enhancing  surveillance-related  capacity  in  their  respective  countries.  In  particular,  the 
deputies asked that the longer, on-the-job type training component be retained in any future 
ADB program to complement the shorter and more structured training program. The format and 
scope of the training program in the proposed TA was discussed with the ASEAN deputy 
finance ministers at the October meeting in Myanmar, and all deputies supported the proposal. 
The capacity to conduct economic surveillance activities effectively in many of the ASEAN 
countries, particularly in the new member countries, remains weak, and further support is 
warranted. The TA is designed to bring together the strengths identified in the two previous 
capacity-building TAs, while addressing their shortcomings. The objectives, scope, financing 
plans, and implementation arrangements are reflected in this paper. The TA framework is 
attached as Appendix 1.3

II.  ISSUES 
5.  The ASEAN economies participate in both national and global surveillance processes 
that are led by IMF. The results of the national surveillance activities undertaken by IMF are 
largely confidential and are shared only with the concerned governments, and focus mainly on 
domestic policy concerns. While global surveillance activities provide an important context for 
domestic policy formulation, they do not contain the detailed analyses that are needed to 
support effective policy dialogue among regional economic partners. ASP seeks to fill these 
gaps by facilitating the exchange of crucial economic and financial information among countries, 
by developing an institutional process that will permit more effective coordination of responses 
to evolving economic and financial circumstances both within the region and outside, and by 
focusing on sectoral and structural as well as macroeconomic issues. Through the opportunities 
it offers for peer monitoring consultation and dialogue, ASP will also act as a vehicle to help 
improve national policies and facilitate economic reform. 
 
6.  For ASP to meet its stated objectives, the capacity to undertake economic surveillance 
activities in ASEAN countries needs to be enhanced. ADB was requested to play a key role in 
enhancing capacity and has been responding since the inception of ASP. The first phase of the 
training program had ASEAN officials from Brunei Darussalam (on a full cost recovery basis, 
see footnote 4), Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao People’s Democratic Republic (PDR), Myanmar, 
Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam. The training program focused mainly on developing on-
the-job experience of economic surveillance and policy analysis. Each cohort of ASEAN officials 
spent approximately 3 months at ADB as secondees undergoing training. The focus was on the 
following activities: managing macroeconomic and financial information systems; monitoring 
global  economic  developments  that  affect  opportunities  and  create  risks  for  the  region; 
developing country macroeconomic and financial frameworks; conducting country policy reviews 
and consultations; and identifying sound institutional practices for macroeconomic and financial 
management. 
 
7.  ADB staff and consultants closely supervised and regularly evaluated the work of the 
secondees.  The feedback was overwhelmingly positive, with secondees expressing the general 
view  that  the  training  has  been  very  beneficial  in  building  their  capacity  to  perform 
surveillance-related tasks in their home countries. 
 
8.  The shorter and more structured second phase 3-week training program (footnote 2) had 
participants from all 10 ASEAN countries.  It is worth noting that Singapore and Malaysia, who 
had not participated in the 3-month program, sent representatives to the shorter program.   
 
9.  The feedback from the participants of the 3-month program and the 3-week program will 
be an important input in preparing the training course for the second phase. Indeed, the third 
phase will bring together the strong points of both the 3-month and 3-week program and try to 
avoid their shortcomings. For example, the structured refresher course in macroeconomics, 
focusing on conceptual and policy aspects, from the 3-week program will be retained in a 
slightly modified form, as will the problem-solving type exercises using the case study approach.  
The on-the-job type training used in the 3-month program will also be retained although in a 
more compact and refined manner, and much of this will form the special topics (or second) part 
of the training program. The feedback suggests that various aspects of the 3-month program 
can  be  either  remodeled  or  restructured  to  fit  into  a  shorter  time  frame.  Responses  from 
participants in the 2 programs suggest that the duration of the third phase program should lie 
somewhere between 3 weeks and 3 months.  With the changes proposed, the third phase

3 
course can be conducted in a time frame of 6 weeks. Much of the course and training material 
developed in the first and second phases can be used, with minor alterations. 
  
10.  ADB  is  uniquely  positioned  to  assist  ASEAN  in  developing  its  regional  economic 
surveillance initiative through the proposed training program. ADB has accumulated extensive 
experience  in  an  area  that  its  charter  expressly  mandates—the  promotion  of  regional 
cooperation. ADB has also worked widely with its developing member countries (DMCs) to 
promote structural reform of their financial sectors and is continuing to build expertise in this 
area. In a context where change and reform at the global, regional, and national levels are 
needed, regional development organizations, such as ADB, have an important role to play in 
complementing the resources of lMF and the World Bank. ADB's technical assistance resources 
are a particularly effective modality for capacity building and institutional strengthening that are 
essential for a credible surveillance process, as well as meeting the broader challenge of 
building more robust financial and economic systems. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The  TA’s  principal  objective  is  to  train  officials  from  ASEAN  member  countries  in 
economic and financial surveillance and related policy-making activities, in support of ASP.  
Since the training program is also available to ASCU staff, the TA will also assist ASCU in its 
economic surveillance activities. A by-product of the training program will be the improved 
information flows and ADB's knowledge of the opportunities and risks facing its DMCs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The proposed 6-week training program can be broadly divided into 2 parts. In the first 
part, which will run for approximately 2 weeks, participants will have an intensive review of 
macroeconomic  analysis  and  the  interrelated  accounting  and  analytic  framework  used  by 
government authorities in establishing their macroeconomic and financial policies.  The material 
will  be  developed  from  a  practitioner’s  perspective  and  will  discuss  the  various  important 
economic issues that policy makers have faced in recent years. Problem-solving workshops in 
fiscal,  monetary,  and  balance-of-payments  issues  and  in  overall  economic  and  financial 
programming will allow participants to use concepts developed in the lecture material. Building 
on this background, the second part of the program will focus on specialized topics of economic 
surveillance. The topics will include the development of macro and micro prudential indicators of 
financial system soundness, formulation of early warning systems (EWS) of economic crisis, 
analysis of leading economic indicators, use of global and regional surveillance information 
systems, issues and progress in developing a new international financial architecture, and 
issues relating to macroeconomic policy and poverty reduction.  
 
13.  Although participation in this training program will be open to all ASEAN countries,4 it is 
expected, and indeed intended, that the new member countries of ASEAN participate to a high 
degree. The capacity to conduct economic monitoring and surveillance activities in countries

14.  Officials  will  be  selected  from  the  finance  ministries  and  central  banks  of  ASEAN 
countries  or  from  the  ASEAN  secretariat  in  Jakarta.  They  will  have  these  minimum 
qualifications: 
 
(i)  a  bachelor’s  degree  (or  the  equivalent)  in  economics  or  finance  from  a 
recognized university, and preferably a postgraduate qualification in the same, 
(ii)  at least five years relevant professional work experience, and 
(iii)  fluency in written and spoken English. 
 
15.  While  governments  will  initially  select  candidates  for  training  and  forward  their 
nominations to ASCU, ADB will retain the right to decline nominations that do not meet the 
criteria. It is expected that officials who are selected for training at ADB will be assigned 
responsibilities for ASEAN surveillance activities on completion of the training. A precondition 
for participation in the training program will be the commitment of the participants to resume 
duties with either their governments or ASCU in Jakarta. 
 
16.  The TA will finance the training of approximately 30 mid-level officials in 3 batches of 10 
ministry of finance and central bank officials within 1 year. ADB staff and consultants will handle 
the training. ADB will provide round-trip airfare, per diem, and mission travel expenses for the 
trainees. During the training period, the respective governments will meet the salaries of the 
trainees. The trainees will not be employees of ADB. Any privileges and immunities that the 
Philippine Government grants to trainees will be a matter for negotiation between ASEAN and 
the Government of the Philippines.  
 
17.  The activities will expose trainees to economic and financial data systems, emerging 
data  standards,  EWS  and  macroeconomic  models,  methods  of  policy  analysis,  codes  of 
conduct for monetary and fiscal policy, and international standards in areas such as bank 
supervision and securities regulation. Taken together, these activities will help develop the 
technical skills and practical experience needed to sustain and support full ownership of ASP. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
18.  The total estimated cost of the TA is $390,000, of which $300,000 will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  TA  funding  program.  The  ASEAN  secretariat  and  ASEAN  member 
governments will provide counterpart support including salaries of participants estimated at 
$90,000. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The ASEAN secretariat will be the Implementing Agency for the TA. Implementation will 
be conditional on ASEAN's formal agreement—contained in a Letter of Agreement—to the 
structure and conditions of this TA. 
 
20.  ASCU within the ASEAN secretariat is responsible for ASP and will be responsible for  
implementing the TA. ASCU’s responsibilities are to screen and make the final list of trainees for 
ADB's consideration, and to maintain all official contact with national governments and their 
respective agencies.

5 
 
21.  The trainees will be located in the ASEAN Surveillance Technical Support Unit (ASTSU) 
within ADB. ASTSU will have no autonomous implementation responsibilities for the TA, and its 
operational assignments will be determined by Regional Economic Monitoring Unit (REMU) in 
collaboration with ASCU. ADB staff and consultants will train ASTSU trainees, and ADB will 
provide other resources needed for the routine operations and viability of ASTSU. 
 
22.  Responsibility for executing the TA will rest with ADB. REMU, in consultation with the 
regional  departments  and  the  Economics  and  Research  Department,  will  take  the  lead  in 
executing the TA. The TA will be for 12 months, starting in January 2003; it is scheduled to be 
completed by the end of December 2003. 
 
23.  The terms of reference for two international consultants to be engaged for the training 
program are in Appendix 3. One international consultant will have experience in all aspects of 
macroeconomics and financial monitoring activities and will have taught macroeconomics and 
financial  programming  to  developing  country  officials  of  various  backgrounds  in  a  short-
course/workshop environment. The other international consultant will be an expert in developing 
financial and capital markets including developing indicators of financial soundness and models 
of EWS, as well as financial and corporate governance matters included in the current effort to 
strengthen the international financial architecture. The TA provides for 3 person-months of 
international  consulting  services,  with  each  international  consultant  to  be  engaged  for  1.5 
person-months over the period of the TA. Recruitment will follow ADB's Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis for 
Technical Training and Capacity Building in Support of the ASEAN Economic Surveillance 
Process Phase III, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  Two international consultants will be engaged. One will prepare and present the module 
on macroeconomics and financial programming. The consultant will have experience in teaching 
macroeconomics  and  financial  programming  to  developing  country  officials  of  various 
backgrounds, in a short-course/workshop environment. The consultant will be engaged for 
approximately 1.5 person-months. 
 
2.  The second international consultant will prepare the materials and present the special 
topics sessions. The consultant will be an expert in developing financial and capital markets, 
including designing indicators of financial soundness, models of early warning systems, and 
leading economic indicators, as well as financial and corporate governance matters included in 
the current effort to strengthen the international financial architecture. The consultant will be 
engaged for approximately 1.5 person-months.
